observations.summary: Production areas contained difficult-to-clean equipment and surfaces with observed rust and discoloration near sterile compounding areas.
Puddled liquid was found in a cabinet near the segregated compounding area (SCA), indicating poor housekeeping practices.
Sinks were located directly adjacent to the ISO 5 area, posing a potential contamination risk.
The SCA had a sink located near the ISO-5 compounding area and shared storage with materials used in the ISO-5 area, potentially leading to cross-contamination.
Beta-lactam drugs were produced without adequate containment, segregation, and cleaning to prevent cross-contamination; lack of policies to deactivate these drugs after production.
Quality control unit responsibilities and procedures were not fully written and followed; several key documents were not reviewed, finalized or followed correctly.
Protective apparel was not consistently worn to protect drug products from contamination during production.
Aseptic processing areas were deficient; equipment used to control aseptic conditions (ISO 5 LFH) showed rust and damage.
Aseptic processing areas lacked a sufficient system for cleaning and disinfecting the room and equipment.
Operators failed to consistently follow aseptic procedures, such as disinfecting gloves and items before entering ISO 5, handling vials improperly, and exposing skin to the open environment.
Procedures to prevent microbiological contamination lacked adequate validation of aseptic and sterilization processes, including insufficient smoke studies.
Batch production and control records were incomplete, lacking in-process and laboratory control results; visual inspection documentation was inadequate.
The facility failed to submit an initial product report to the FDA upon registration as a 503B outsourcing facility.

Environmental monitoring and microbiological surface sampling were deficient during aseptic filling operations.  Non-sterile gloves were used, and there was no assurance that secondary contact surfaces were adequately cleaned.
Biological indicator (BI) placement during validation did not ensure that the BI reached all product contact surfaces, compromising sterility assurance.
Pinholes in the [redacted] exposed the Grade A environment to potential contamination from the Grade D environment, jeopardizing sterility.
The DS manufacturing area lacked adequate controls for pressure, humidity, and environmental monitoring to ensure product quality.

Cleaning procedures for product-contact equipment lacked assurance of effectiveness in preventing carryover and cross-contamination. Swab sampling wasn't performed during cleaning validation for multi-product and dedicated equipment or DS downstream manufacturing vessels.
The use of [redacted] product from a less stringent generation process did not assure product quality for the final product.
